At 19:37 17/04/2008, you wrote:

>On Thu, Apr 17, 2008 at 1:26 PM, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
> >
> >  Finally, while it is cool that your program beats you guys at checkers, it
> >  might not solely be because of the HyperNEAT-driven AI. The 
> program is also
> >  using alpha-beta and the like. I'll bet a rather poor position evaluator
> >  plus Alpha-Beta with a decent amount of lookahead could beat me at
> > checkers, even if I was better at evaluating board positions on average.
>
>Good point, Jeff. This was one of my big problems with Blondie24
>(although to the author's credit, he did address the issue, along with
>many other objections). The question is the amount of work being done
>by the ANN vs. the brute-force approach of tree search. The Blondie24
>network did better than a crude board estimation such as simply
>counting the number of opponent and friendly pieces on the board, but
>not a whole lot better.

Hi,

So how about using a search pruning method but evolve a separate 
network(s) to make decisions about when to prune.

That feels to me a bit like how I play games, mentally doing a bit of 
look ahead and then deciding whether to do more look ahead according 
to what I've found.  But not necessarily using exactly the same 
heuristics for shallow and deep evaluation...

Of course, that might leave you with a need to do more than assess 
single boards.  e.g. if I've looked ahead to several very different 
situations, I probably want to do some sort of general comparison of 
the broad situations before picking one or two to concentrate 
on.  OTOH, maybe the brute-force of a computer approach can 
compensate for that and still be a bit more like natural thought.

This isn't have expert players play, of course...

Ian

Oh, b.t.w. great paper Ken and Jason...
